div.p: 1. The current general words for dwelling in a place for some considerable time are jū 居 and chǔ 處 (all ant. xíng 行 "travel").
2. Shè 舍 and sù 宿 refer to spending the night in a certain place.
3. Guǎn 館 refers to spending the night in a visitor's hostel (which is China's ancient answer to a hotel).
4. Qī 棲 refers to a temporary or non-voluntary stay of any length, typically of an informal kind. See ROOST
5. Xìn 信 is sometimes used as a technical term for staying in a place for two nights.
6. Cì 次 is sometimes used as a technical term for spending more than two days in a certain place.
7. Jì 寄 and yù 寓 refer to staying in some place for a strictly limited space of time.
8. Jùn 軍 refers specifically to an army encamping in a certain place for a limited time.
NB: Zhù 住 is post-Buddhist (SIX DYNASTIES)
rough draft to BEGIN TO identify synonym group members for analysis, based on CL etc. 18.11.2003. CH ／

bibl.title: A Dictionary of Selected Synonyms in the Principal Indo-European Languages

note.p: incolere is a transitive verb referring to permanent residence in the object.
habitare takes a prepositional phrase as an object and is synonymous with incolere.

entry.def: NB: Zhù 住 is post-Buddhist (SIX DYNASTIES)

sense.def: live in a contextually determinate place
dwell with the contextually determinate N
stay in, dwell in (a mental state)

entry.def: Xìn 信 is sometimes used as a technical term for staying in a place for two nights.

sense.def: SHI; ZUO Xiang 18: spend a couple of nights (below the city walls, presumably in tents)
dwell in, stay in, live inBuddh. historiographic writings: have one's permament residence in (i.e. as one's main place of teaching activities)

note.p: This meaning is rather common in vernacular texts, escpecially of the Tang period; there are also examples in Tang poetry (白居易：《自提小圓》); BIANWEN, fasc. 3; SOUSHENJI

sense.def: sit at a place > to live in/at; dwell in/at (this is a meaning common in vernacular texts of the Tang)
make one's home in; settle in
OBI: take up residence in (a house); dwell
settle peacefully in (a place), be at peace in (a place, also abstractly: a social position)
make one's home in N; have one's home in N SHIJI: 家焉

entry.def: Jì 寄 and yù 寓 refer to staying in some place for a strictly limited space of time.

sense.def: seek lodging with for a time, find security for a time with; stay with for a time

entry.def: Shè 舍 and sù 宿 refer to spending the night in a certain place.

sense.def: spend the night in a contextually determinate place; later more generally: dwell

entry.def: Jì 寄 and yù 寓 refer to staying in some place for a strictly limited space of time.

sense.def: come to lodge in, happen to reside in for a time; stay with for a time
lodge (somebody N1) temporarily at (a place N2)無寓人於我室
build up the numbers of the population in, populate (an area)

entry.def: The current general words for dwelling in a place for some considerable time are jū 居 and chǔ 處 (all ant. xíng 行 "travel").

sense.def: deciding where to live; choice of dwelling place
choose to live in a place
to settle (in a place) to find a dwelling (somewhere); take up residence in
dwell in for longish time LY 15 居是邦 "when living in such-and-such a state"
settle in, go to reside in, take up residence in
be situated in; have one's (permanent, or at least lasting) abode in; spend one's time (with someone); transferred: be in (such-and-such a condition)
live in the contextually determinate place N
cause N1 to live in the place N2
deploy one's troops for aggressive purposes at, encamp at
live in a simple hut in N

entry.def: Qī 棲 refers to a temporary or non-voluntary stay of any length, typically of an informal kind. See ROOST

sense.def: cause (oneself) to live in 棲身

entry.def: Cì 次 is sometimes used as a technical term for spending more than two days in a certain place.

sense.def: OBI: camp for a few days (as of an army in a military campaign), encampTAKASHIMA: all occurrences of the OBI graph (commonly transcribed as 次 ) with a horizontal stroke undertneath the graph are verbal, whereas all nominal uses of the graph do not have this horizontal stroke.
make a halt in; spend some days in

entry.def: Shè 舍 and sù 宿 refer to spending the night in a certain place.

sense.def: set up one's army camp; stop for the night
take temporary lodging (with somebody or in a certain place); (of army) encamp at
spend the night in (a place); take temporary lodging with or at
pass one's time, live in a certain place vt(oN)
be in (a place), stay in (a place); stay among (the barbarians etc); choose to dwell in, choose as one's abode; take up private residence in
cause N1 to take up residence in N2

entry.def: Jùn 軍 refers specifically to an army encamping in a certain place for a limited time.
Guǎn 館 refers to spending the night in a visitor's hostel (which is China's ancient answer to a hotel).

sense.def: spend the night in a hostel/hotel for visitors

sense.def: BUDDH: hang one's monk's staff on the wall > become a resident monk in a monastery (also liúxī 留錫)
reside at, dwell in a contextually determinate place
reside at, dwell in, stay in
settle at a contextually determinate place

SHIJI: spend a night in N
SHIJI: dwell as guest in the place N, stay as guest with N
live in hiding; live in obscurity; live in such a way as to hide from public life SHIJI: 與高祖隱 "lived in hiding together with Gaozu"
